awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Socio-demographic variation in experiences of maternal healthcare in relation to conceptions of health crisis
awd_abstract_narration:
Maternal mortality has decreased significantly over the last century, yet remains highly variable, impacting how people understand and experience maternal healthcare. Significant research has shed light on how factors such as proximity to healthcare and socioeconomic status impact maternal health. Yet, maternal characteristics intersect with numerous other sociological variables and histories to impact how they use and experience maternal healthcare. This doctoral dissertation research investigates how variation in concepts of maternal health crises affects how women intersect with mainstream and alternative forms of healthcare. It trains a graduate student in scientific cultural anthropology theory and methods and disseminates findings broadly to academic and policy audiences. 

The researcher investigates how clinicians and patients understand concepts of maternal health crises and how this impacts delivery of and experiences of care. Using interviews and participant observation, the investigator asks: how individual factors intersect to affect patient experiences; how clinicians’ understandings of crises impact maternal healthcare; and how patient and clinician experiences intersect in shaping maternal health outcomes. The project is responsive to recent calls to investigate how perceptions of public health articulate with patient experiences in driving health and welfare among mothers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Funding from National Science Foundation’s Dissertation Research Improvement Grant was used to continue work on a 15-month ethnographic study of landscapes of care in the context of the African American maternal mortality epidemic in urban and rural Georgia. During the project, I lived jointly in Atlanta, Georgia, and Albany, Georgia, which reflects a significant change from one of the proposed sites of the project. As explained in my proposal, one of my primary ethnographic goals was to work via useful methods while in the field, which in this case, entailed me choosing an alternative rural site for the project to support the primary organization with which I partnered on their rural health project. I found that this site could address the questions I set out to answer in the NSF proposal. Working in Albany and surrounding areas of Southwest Georgia also raised new questions and proved to be ideal for understanding the intersections of Blackness, rurality, and maternal health. 

 

I began using National Science Foundation funds for the project in April 2024 and continued ethnographic research through November 2024. Funds supported my unpaid position as the research and administrative intern for the Atlanta Doula Collective (ADC). The Atlanta Doula Collective is a 501c3 nonprofit organization based in Atlanta, Georgia with a mission to address the maternal health crisis among Black families in Georgia through doula support and community education. The Collective is comprised of twelve doulas and one midwife working mostly in the greater Atlanta area, although most have served families across the state and the region. I worked most closely with the midwife-CEO of the organization, who fundraised and organized the public facing work of the organization. In my role, I took on event planning, including organizing catering and space usage, assisted with childbirth education programming, managed communication, including authoring the organizational newsletter, and most importantly, helped to develop the Georgia Black Doula Network. The ADC’s CEO envisioned creating a statewide doula organization that had the capacity to train new doulas in underresourced areas of the state to offer frontline maternal health support to the most vulnerable communities. I helped do the preliminary research to get the organization started, conducting field visits to Albany, during which I collected ethnographic data and assisted the ADC with generating interest in doula training in Southwest Georgia.

 

I observed home birth midwifery care, doula support, and clinical care at the Center for Black Women’s Wellness and the Atlanta Birth Center during the fieldwork period. In addition to observing and/or working with these professionals during the fieldwork period, I conducted formal interviews with approximately 30 of them. In addition to participant-observation of direct health care, I also conducted a significant portion of the fieldwork with public health strategists in various sites. I served on a Georgia Maternal Health Task Force, reviewing policy proposals and helping to draft educational materials. I also the Healthy Mothers, Healthy Babies of Georgia conference as a representative for the Atlanta Doula Collective/Georgia Black Doula Network. I attended public health department meetings in Dekalb, Fulton, and Early counties. Through the publicly engaged angle of the project, I interviewed and interacted with state lawmakers. Via my close interactions with doulas, I was able to interview 50 Black mothers who had sought their care, as well as observe these mothers and converse with them informally in spaces of doula care and advocacy.

 

In addition to developing cultural anthropologies of crisis, medicine, and Black feminist theory, contributes to new standards for best practice maternal health care. In the wake of concerning data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s 2017 maternal mortality review (CDC 2022), and the 2021 Congressional initiation of a Momnibus Act to “comprehensively address every dimension of the maternal health crisis in America” (Adams and Underwood 2021), federal institutions have mobilized around a need for more and better-quality data about how and where maternal health and care happen in the United States. This study contributes to the production of a unique, expansive, and nuanced dataset about Black women’s lived experiences and the nature of care infrastructures in areas of the country hardest hit by the impact of maternal mortality rates and disparities. Employing long-term, multi-sited ethnographic research practices with a range of actors and organizations on the holistic landscape of maternal health care in the U.S. South, this research responds directly to the call from the Momnibus bills to “improve data collection processes…to better understand the causes of the maternal health crisis in the United States and inform solutions to address it,” (Adams and Underwood 2021). Some of the findings of my ethnographic project have been disseminated via the documentary Cradled in Culture(2024) produced by the Georgia Black Doula Network, as well as being used to design doula training currently being implemented in Southwest Georgia.

 


Last Modified: 03/18/2025
Modified by: Ayodele Osa Foster-McCray

I observed home birth midwifery care, doula support, and clinical care at the Center for Black Womens Wellness and the Atlanta Birth Center during the fieldwork period. In the wake of concerning data from the Centers for Disease Control and Preventions 2017 maternal mortality review (CDC 2022), and the 2021 Congressional initiation of a Momnibus Act to comprehensively address every dimension of the maternal health crisis in America (Adams and Underwood 2021), federal institutions have mobilized around a need for more and better-quality data about how and where maternal health and care happen in the United States.
